STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 16, 2019
Katherine Page-Sander
Hands Across The Water
781 Avis Drive, Suite 200
Ann Arbor, MI 48108
RE: License #: CB810201161
Hands Across The Water
Suite 200
781 Avis Drive, Suite 200
Ann Arbor, MI 48108
Dear Mrs. Page-Sander:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
7/15/19. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

Ann Arbor, MI 48108

781 Avis Drive, Suite 200
Ann Arbor, MI 48108

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
One of eight licensing files did not meet this requirement. The license was due for
renewal by 6/11/19. However, the application was provided on 5/1/19, only 41 days
before expiration.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
One of three borrowed home records did not meet this requirement. The 10/23/18
annual evaluation for the home was received, but not endorsed by staff at the
agency.
This is a repeat violation- 6/23/18 interim review; CAP approved 8/7/18.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(2) The borrowing agency is responsible for securing the items
identified in subrules (1) (d), (e), (g), (h), and (i) of this rule
annually for the duration of the child’s placement.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
4

One of three borrowed bed records did not meet this requirement. A Foster Parent
Agency Agreement was signed in April 2018. A new agreement should have been
signed in April 2019, when the annual evaluation was completed.
This is a repeat violation- 6/23/18 interim review; CAP approved 8/7/18.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(a) The provision of routine medical care.
(b) The provision of emergency medical, surgical, and dental
care.
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months before
being placed in foster care or a new physical examination shall
be completed within 30 calendar days after being placed in
foster care.
One of eight files did not meet this requirement.
The youth was returned home from March to November 2018. Upon re-entering care
on 11/14/18, the youth was due for an 18-month check-up. In addition, the rule
requires a physical exam within 3 months prior to placement, or within 30 days of
placement. The youth’s prior medical exam was on 2/20/18, and did not meet this
requirement. Therefore, a new medical was due by 12/14/18. The youth did not
receive this exam until 1/11/19. The agency reported that the delay was due to the
birth mother calling the doctor’s office directly and cancelling visits scheduled by the
relative caregiver. The worker reported explaining the requirement to the mother
several times, however she was reluctant to allow the appointment. After several
discussions, the mother allowed the appointment. However, the appointment was
then late.
R 400.12603 Policy and procedures
The agency shall document that the policies and procedures
were provided to all persons making inquiry about the agency’s
services.
5

Four of six prospective adoptive family case files did not meet this requirement. The
case files did not have documentation to verify that the applicants received the
agencies policies and procedures.
R 400.12604 Orientation and application.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for adoption before an adoptive application is
provided.
One of six prospective adoptive family case files did not meet this requirement. The
case file did not have documentation to verify that the applicant attended
Orientation.
R 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
Three of six adoption case files did not have documentation that the applicants
received a copy of the completed adoption evaluation and recommendation.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06h Caseworker contact
All casework contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, this
includes attempted contacts and missed appointments, and all
pertinent information obtained must be summarized and
included in the appropriate section of the case service plan. All
face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within five
business days of the contact.
6

Three of eight foster care case files have contacts that were entered into MiSACWIS
beyond the required timeframe.
File 1: Foster home visit from 1/25/19 was entered 4/26/19.
File 2: Foster home visit from 6/21/18 was entered 7/2/18. FHV from 9/17/18 was
entered 9/26/18. FHV from 11/6/18 was entered 11/20/18. FHV from 12/19/18 was
entered 1/3/19. FHV from 1/2/19 was entered 1/11/19.
File 3: Foster home visit from 11/29/18 was entered 1/11/19. FHV from 12/11/18 was
entered 1/11/19.
This is a repeat violation- 6/23/18 interim review; CAP approved 8/7/18.
ADM 300 Adoption assessment
Page 1
The DHHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be
completed by the adoption worker and approved by the
adoption supervisor within 45 calendar days of case
acceptance.
Three of six DHHS (state ward) adoption cases had Child Assessments completed
beyond the 45 day timeframe.
File 1: Referral was accepted on 6/5/18, CAA completed 7/23/18 (48 days).
File 2: Referral was accepted 8/27/18, CAA completed 11/2/18 (67 days).
File 3: Referral was accepted 2/1/19, CAA completed 3/21/19 (48 days).
ADM 330 Quarterly adoption progress report
Page 1
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report. The
adoption worker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child during each quarter prior to the adoption
supervision period for the purpose of completing the DHHS-614.
The child assessment may serve as the initial quarterly report if
it is completed within the required quarterly reporting period and
attached to the DHHS-614 form.
7

Two of six DHHS (state ward) adoption case files had quarterly reports that were
completed late.
File 1: CAA completed 9/10/18; quarterly reports completed 11/12/18, 2/4/19, and
6/5/19(late).
File 2: CAA completed 11/2/18; quarterly reports completed 1/18/19 and 5/3/19
(late).
FOM 722-09 Updated service plan
Supervisory approval- prior to finalizing, the USP along with the
required assessments (FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed
and approved by the foster care supervisor only after a face-to-
face meeting with the worker. Case service plan approval
process requires the foster care supervisor to review and
approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the report date.
Two of twenty one USPs had late supervisor approval/signatures.
File 1: 12/13/18 USP approved by supervisor on 1/20/19 (38 days).
File 2: 3/26/19 USP approved by supervisor on 4/24/19 (29 days).
This is a repeat violation:
 6/23/18 interim review; CAP approved 8/7/18.
 7/6/17 renewal review; CAP approved 8/7/17.
FOM 722-06b Family team meeting
Page 1
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers, foster
parents, children, youth, and may also include extended family,
friends, neighbors, community-based service providers, community
representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian children, or other
professionals involved with the family.
One of eight foster care records had an FTM in which the parents did not attend, nor
was there documentation that they were invited to participate.
This is a repeat violation- 6/23/18 interim review; CAP approved 8/7/18.
FOM 722-06h Foster care action summary
The foster care action summary, DHS-69, is used whenever
there is “action” on a case.
All foster care cases where there is:
1. A replacement
2. Termination from foster care placement
3. A change in FC worker
8

4. Agency change/transfer to another FC
agency
5. A change in a parent’s living situation
6. Foster care transfer to adoption.
One of two closed foster care records did not have a closing summary (DHHS 69)
on file.
This is a repeat violation- 6/23/18 interim review; CAP approved 8/7/18.
FOM 722-08C Parent agency treatment plan and service agreement
Page 2
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and
service agreement, the parent is given a copy for review. Foster
care workers need to ensure the parent understands all areas
within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14 and older
must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is unavailable or
refuses to sign the PATP, foster care workers must identify and
document additional action needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the PATP. As the goals are achieved, modified or
expanded, the updated PATP will reflect this process. Parents
and youths age 14 and older must participate in the
development of each updated treatment plan, allowing for
opportunity to evaluate their progress towards completing goals.
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities
provided by the foster care worker to assist the foster
parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
CI 17-099
When the treatment plan is completed, signatures for all
appropriate case members must be obtained. Signatures from
all appropriate case members, including youth ages 14 and
older for foster care and youth ages 11 and older for juvenile
justice, should be obtained before the corresponding court
hearing. All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate case
members within 30 days of the report date.
9

Eleven of twenty one PATPs did not have signatures by parents or foster parents,
within the required 30 day timeframe.
File 1:
12/13/18 PATP- Foster parent signed 2/5/19, mom signed 2/5/19
File 2:
4/22/19 PATP- Missing parent signature. Treatment plan indicates that a copy was
mailed to the parent, however a signature has not been obtained as of 7/15/19.
1/22/19 PATP- Foster parent signed 3/20/19.
File 3:
7/17/18 PATP- One parent’s signature undated. Second parent signed 9/17/18.
Foster parent signed 9/17/18
10/5/18 PATP- One parent signed 1/30/19. Second parent signed 12/20/18.
1/3/19 PATP- Missing foster parent signature. One parent’s signature is undated.
Second parents signed 6/6/19.
File 4:
5/9/19 PATP- Report indicates the PATP was given the parent at the home visit, but
a signature was not obtained. As of 7/15/19, no signature has been received.
5/9 PATP- Foster parent signed 6/25/19.
File 5:
3/22/19 PATP- Foster parent signed 6/20/19.
2/22 PATP- Foster parent signature is undated.
9/26 PATP- Foster parent signed 11/28/18.
IV. ANALYST SAFETY REVIEW:
Foster parent 3 reported not receiving a medical passport. Foster parent
reported not participating in a family team meeting or providing input and
signing the case service plan.
The case record was reviewed and found that the case was transferred from DHHS
to HATW 1/16/19. Medical passports were provided to and signed by the foster
parent on 1/31/19, 2/11/19, and 6/17/19. In addition, it was determined that the
foster parent participated in an FTM on 4/15/19. The FTM form is signed by both
foster parents. Lastly, the foster parent signed the 1/16/19 and 4/16/19 PATPs,
indicating that they were involved with planning and received a copy of the service
plan. Therefore, the agency is found to be in compliance regarding these concerns.
However, there is one violation due to late PATP signatures. The FP signed the
1/16/19 and 4/16/19 PATP on 6/13/19. As these were not signed within 30 days of
report completion, this is a violation of FOM 722-08C, as noted in the above findings.
Foster parent 4 reported not receiving a medical passport. Foster parent
reported not providing input and signing the case service plan.
10

A review of the case record found that the case transferred to HATW on 4/26/19.
Documentation in the file shows that the foster parent was provided with a medical
passport at the first home visit on 4/30/19.
Regarding the concern of lack of foster parent input, the FP participated in an FTM
on 5/22/19, and has been active in conversation with the caseworker during visits.
Due to this case transferring in April 2019, the first PATP was just completed. The
PATP was then signed by the foster parent on 6/20/19, after the analyst visit. Any
concerns about not being involved in or signing the PATP prior to April were the
responsibility of the previous agency.
Relative 6 reported that the foster care worker has made only 4 unannounced
visits in 3 1/2 years. The relative reported that there is no monthly sibling
visitation taking place.
A review of the case file found that this case transferred to HATW 11/8/18, therefore
any concerns that took place greater than seven months ago, are the responsibility
of the previous agency.
The case file detailed unannounced home visits on 1/3/19, 4/12/19. Sibling visits
occurred on 11/27/18, 12/18/18, 1/29/19, 2/19/19, 3/28/19 and 4/17/19. The sibling
was then adopted on 4/10/19 and sibling visits were no longer required by policy.
In foster home 7, one of the foster children reported not to be involved in the
development of their service plan as well as not participating in any semi-
annual transitional meetings.
A review of the case record found that this case transferred to HATW on 8/2/18.
Since transferring to this agency, the youth signed and received copies of 5/4/18,
8/2/18, 11/27/18, 1/29/19, and 4/25/19 PATPs. The youth participated in semi-
annual transition meetings (FTM) on 11/27/18 and 5/10/19. However, it was noted
that the youth did not attend any other service plan FTMs.
V. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
Borrowed Beds- Two of three borrowed home records held placement lists which
appear to match the most recent annual/renewal inspection report. However, the
placement lists were undated. Therefore, it could not be determined when they were
updated, to confirm compliance with rule 326 (2). The agency was advised to
request updated placement records with each annual/renewal, and date the
placement list on the day it is received.
VI. CONSULTATION
The agency did not require consultation during this review.
11

VII. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
On 12/7/18 a Special Evaluation was initiated due to an allegation that an adult
household member had duct taped a child’s mouth, and handcuffed his wrists to a
bed at night. Upon investigation with DHHS, the foster home was found to be in
violation of licensing rules and revocation was recommended on 3/7/19. Based on
the information contained in the SER, it appears the agency completed a thorough
evaluation and made a proper recommendation.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
On 11/7/18 a Special Evaluation was initiated due to an allegation that the foster
parents physically discipline the children in the home. Upon investigation with
DHHS, the foster home was found to be in violation of licensing rules due to
spanking the children in the home. A Corrective Action Plan was developed and
completed by the foster parents. Discipline continues to be monitored by the foster
care worker and licensing worker. Based on the information in the SER, the agency
completed a thorough evaluation and took the proper steps to educate the foster
parents and monitor the home for safety concerns.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A CAP was required after the July 2018 interim review. The CAP, approved
8/7/2018, addressed the violations found during the interim review. The CAP was
referenced while completing the current renewal evaluation and found that few
repeat violations occurred. Overall, the agency appears to be following their 2018
CAP, as shown through improvement in several areas.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules, ISEP requirements, and contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
July 16, 2019
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
12

Approved By:
July 16, 2019
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
13
